name: David Dalaithngu
description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

key_work.title: Spotlights: David Dalaithngu
key_work.brief_description: A Yolŋu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. He reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971) and Storm Boy (1976).

constellations_primary.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_primary.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

start.title: Sweet Country
start.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
start.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

constellations_other.name: Native Tongue
constellations_other.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

constellations_other.name: Outlawed
constellations_other.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

end.title: The Nightingale
end.creator_credit: Bruna Papandrea, Jennifer Kent, Kristina Ceyton, Steve Hutensky, Adelaide Film Festival Investment Fund, Creative Wealth Media Finance, FilmNation Entertainment, Made Up Stories, Screen Australia, Screen Tasmania, South Australian Film Corporation, David Smith and Evans Mark
end.headline_credit: Australia, Canada and United States of America, 2019
end.brief_description: In 1825, Claire, a young Irish convict, enlists an Indigenous tracker to chase a British soldier through the rugged Tasmanian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Some like it hot
constellations_other.description: Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly had an eye for designing exceptional garments that worked for non-traditional Hollywood figures. His talent was highlighted when creating the gender non-conforming costumes for characters Joe / Josephine (Tony Curtis) and Jerry / Daphne (Jack Lemmon).

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Jennifer Kent’s follow-up to the critically acclaimed The Babadook, follows an Irish immigrant and Indigenous teen who track down racist colonial police in a brutal revenge drama that resists the dominant narratives of colonialism.

start.title: Spotlights: David Dalaithngu
start.brief_description: A Yolŋu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. He reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971) and Storm Boy (1976).

constellations_primary.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_primary.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: Walkabout
end.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
end.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister and her young brother left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They’re rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

links.description: Legendary Yolngu actor and dancer David Dalaithngu has a career spanning five decades. His first role was in Nicholas Roeg’s Walkabout, where he starred as a First Nations teen leading stranded white children to safety in the Outback.

start.title: Walkabout
start.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
start.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister and her young brother left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They’re rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: Storm Boy
end.creator_credit: Henri Safran, Matt Carroll and South Australian Film Corporation
end.brief_description: Storm Boy is a 1976 Australian drama film based on the book of the same name by Colin Thiele, about a lonely boy and his pet pelicans living in a coastal wilderness with his reclusive father.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

links.description: Five years after wowing audiences with his performance in Walkabout, Dalaithngu starred in the beloved Australian film Stormboy, where he once again serves as a friend and mentor to a young boy and helps him navigate life.

start.title: Walkabout
start.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
start.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister and her young brother left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They’re rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: Ten Canoes
end.creator_credit: Julie Ryan, Rolf de Heer, Fandango and Vertigo Productions
end.brief_description: Filmed in Arnhem Land with a cast of local Indigenous Australians, Ten Canoes interweaves two tales of forbidden love and consequence, spanning thousands of years of Yolngu storytelling, and is told entirely in language.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

links.description: Dalaithngu reportedly learned English while making his first film, adding the language to the list of Indigenous languages he already spoke. Thirty five years after learning English, he narrated Ten Canoes, which is otherwise entirely in the Yolŋu Matha language.

start.title: Ten Canoes
start.creator_credit: Julie Ryan, Rolf de Heer, Fandango and Vertigo Productions
start.brief_description: Filmed in Arnhem Land with a cast of local Indigenous Australians, Ten Canoes interweaves two tales of forbidden love and consequence, spanning thousands of years of Yolngu storytelling, and is told entirely in language.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: The Tracker
end.brief_description: Somewhere in Australia in the early 20th century outback, an Aboriginal man is accused of murdering a white woman. Three white men are on a mission to capture him with the help of an experienced Indigenous man.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: Ten Canoes is the second collaboration between Dalaithngu and Rolf de Heer, the story of which was suggested to de Heer by Dalaithngu after the latter discovered ethnographic photos of his country in Arnhem Land. Their first collaboration was The Tracker.

Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

links.description: In The Tracker, Dalaithngu plays the titular character, who is forced to help a racist colonial policeman track down the alleged killer of a white woman. It, and Sweet Country, are ‘meat pie westerns’, which use western genre conventions to re-examine race relations.

links.description: The Nightingaleis set in Van Diemen’s Land, now known as Tasmania, and features the Palawa Kani language, a near extinct language never before spoken on film. Like Ten Canoes, the film attempts to preserve Indigenous culture through language.

start.title: The Tracker
start.brief_description: Somewhere in Australia in the early 20th century outback, an Aboriginal man is accused of murdering a white woman. Three white men are on a mission to capture him with the help of an experienced Indigenous man.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

end.title: Charlie's Country
end.brief_description: Charlie’s Country is a 2013 Australian drama film directed by Rolf de Heer. It was selected to compete in the Un Certain Regard section at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival where David Gulpilil won the award for Best Actor.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: Rolf de Heer and Dalaithngu’s third collaboration, Charlies Country, was screened in the Un Certain Regard section of the Cannes Film Festival, which won Dalaithngu the Best Actor award for his portrayal of Charlie, an Indigenous man lamenting the loss of his culture.
